pr_title: GH-2497 fix RDF collection processing for malformed collection structures

timeline.message:
GH-2497 test to reproduce issue

Signed-off-by: Håvard Ottestad <hmottestad@gmail.com>

timeline.bodyText: This seems to be a representative example.
timeline.author: hmottestad
timeline.diffHunk:

 		Model actual = Rio.parse(new StringReader(stringWriter.toString()), "", RDFFormat.TURTLE);

+
+		System.out.println("### EXPECTED ###");

+		System.out.println("#################\n");
+
+		Model expected = Rio.parse(new StringReader(data), "", RDFFormat.TURTLE);
+
+		StringWriter stringWriter = new StringWriter();
+		WriterConfig config = new WriterConfig();
+		config.set(BasicWriterSettings.INLINE_BLANK_NODES, true);
+		Rio.write(expected, stringWriter, RDFFormat.TURTLE, config);
+
+		System.out.println("### ACTUAL ###");
+		System.out.println(stringWriter.toString());
+		System.out.println("#################\n");
+
+		Model actual = Rio.parse(new StringReader(stringWriter.toString()), "", RDFFormat.TURTLE);
+		assertTrue(Models.isomorphic(expected, actual));

+				"@prefix xsd:   <http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#> .\n" +
+				"@prefix rdfs:  <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .\n" +
+				"@prefix foaf:  <http://xmlns.com/foaf/0.1/> .\n" +
+				"\n" +
+				"ex:a  ex:list   (_:b0 _:b0) .";
+

replies.author: hmottestad

replies.bodyText: ...that is correct, as far as I can tell. In this case, the bug might actually be in the isomorphism detection, because as far as I can tell those two graphs should be isomorphic.
replies.author: jeenbroekstra

replies.bodyText: Then again, what we're actually after here is no loss of information of course. I'll take a closer look at the writer, see why this node gets inlined when it's referred to more than once.
replies.author: jeenbroekstra

timeline.message:
GH-2479 partial fix for bnode inlining in collections

- fixes simple case but not the more complex one

GH-2497 added another test case

Signed-off-by: Håvard Ottestad <hmottestad@gmail.com>

timeline.bodyText:
I am not sure this one really counts as a bug, to be honest - and even if it does it is a very exotic corner case.
This case is an invalid collection structure in the sense that it links a non-list related poperty (ex:abc) to a bnode that that is directly part of the list structure itself. We are not so much inlining that blank node as just removing it, because the list gets converted to a syntactical shortform where the blank nodes and (rdf:first/rest properties) are just erased.
The actual output for this is:
@prefix ex: <http://example.com/ns#> .
@prefix rdf: <http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#> .

ex:ex1 ex:list ([]) .
[] ex:abc ex:def .

In other words, one list with a single item (a blank node), and a statement with a blank node subject. The fact that in the original file that blank node was the same blank node as the one used in the internal collection structure is lost, but that does not make the output incorrect. There's also a strong whiff of "what the heck are you even doing using a collection blank node like this?!"
We could potentially handle this with a separate test to check if the collection is well-formed before serializing it, but it's going to be costly.
timeline.author: jeenbroekstra

replies.bodyText: I know it's pretty funky. I have no idea how it got produced to be honest. I still think we should consider it a bug though.
replies.author: hmottestad

replies.bodyText: I think the output is incorrect. The pretty printer and bnode inliner should return the same data if you first output n-triples, then pretty print and inline it, then convert it to n-triples again.
replies.author: hmottestad

timeline.message:
ignored failing tests

Signed-off-by: Håvard Ottestad <hmottestad@gmail.com>

GH-2497 extensive check on rdf collections being wellformed

- fixes all outstanding test cases
